Class ArrayOp

  • java.lang.Object
    • ArrayOp

  • public class ArrayOp
extends java.lang.Object
    The ArrayOp class implements operations on arrays of bytes.

    Each object of this class has a fixed instance variable which specifies the required length of input and output arrays. Error message will be thrown if the length of input is incorrect.

    All components of the input are assumed to be nonnegative integers. All components of the output will be nonnegative integers too. For substract and binom, the program checks whether the first input is greater or equal to the second input so that those operations work in the naive way.

    Since:
    2.0
    Version:
    4.0
    Author:
    Yu-jong Tzeng

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      ArrayOp(int n)
      Before doing any operations, the class builds a table of all binomial coefficients m choose k for all 0 <= k <= m <= n.

    • Constructor Detail

      • ArrayOp

        public ArrayOp(int n)
        Before doing any operations, the class builds a table of all binomial coefficients m choose k for all 0 <= k <= m <= n. n is the required length for inputs.
        Parameters:
        n - The max parameter allowed for binomial coefficients in the object. It is also the required length for input arrays and outputs arrays of all methods.

    • Method Detail

      • add

        public byte[] add(byte[] c,
                  byte[] d)
        Return the componentwise sum of two arrays.
        Parameters:
        c - byte[]
        d - byte[]
        Returns:
        An array with the i-th element being c[i] + d[i].

      • binom

        public long binom(byte[] c,
                  byte[] d)
        Return the product of componentwise binomial coefficients. Every component of the first input must be greater or equal to the second input.
        Parameters:
        c - byte[]
        d - byte[]
        Returns:
        The product of all C[ci][di] (C[n][k] is the binomial coeffient).

      • greater

        public boolean greater(byte[] c,
                       byte[] d)
        Return true if the length of two input arrays are the same and every component of the first array is greater or equal to the second.
        Parameters:
        c - byte[]
        d - byte[]
        Returns:
        True if c.length == d.length and c[i] >= d[i] for all i.

      • I

        public int I(byte[] c)
        Return Ic.
        Parameters:
        c - byte[]
        Returns:
        If c = {c1, c2, c3,..}, return 1* c1 + 2* c2 + 3 * c3 + ....

      • I

        public int I(byte[] c,
             int index)
        Return Ic only to the given index.
        Parameters:
        c - byte[]
        index - int
        Returns:
        If c = {c1, c2, c3,..}, return 1* c1 + 2* c2 + 3 * c3 + .... + index * cindex.

      • J

        public long J(byte[] c)
        Return I^c.
        Parameters:
        c - byte[]
        Returns:
        If c = {c1, c2, c3,..}, return 1^(c1) + 2^(c2) + 3^(c3) + ....

      • substract

        public byte[] substract(byte[] c,
                        byte[] d)
        Substract the second input from the first input. Every component of the first input must be great or equal to the second input.
        Parameters:
        c - byte[]
        d - byte[]
        Returns:
        The componentwise difference of the inputs. Send error message if the length of c or d is not equal to n.

      • sum

        public int sum(byte[] c)
        Return |c|.
        Parameters:
        c - byte[]
        Returns:
        If c = {c1, c2, c3,..}, return the sum of all ci.
